articles.headline: Westfield Gives Up San Francisco Mall, Signaling More Pain Ahead
articles.snippet: Retailers have been fleeing the city’s downtown, and some analysts say there may be more to come. It’s an issue facing various downtowns around the United States.
articles.abstract: Retailers have been fleeing the city’s downtown, and some analysts say there may be more to come. It’s an issue facing various downtowns around the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nordstrom. Old Navy. Anthropologie. H&M. Crate & Barrel.
articles.byline: By Jordyn Holman and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: Judge in Trump Documents Case Has Scant Criminal Trial Experience
articles.snippet: Judge Aileen M. Cannon, under scrutiny for past rulings favoring the former president, has presided over only a few criminal cases that went to trial.
articles.abstract: Judge Aileen M. Cannon, under scrutiny for past rulings favoring the former president, has presided over only a few criminal cases that went to trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: Aileen M. Cannon, the Federal District Court judge assigned to preside over former President Donald J. Trump’s classified documents case, has scant experience running criminal trials, calling into question her readiness to handle what is likely to be an extraordinarily complex and high-profile courtroom clash.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: They Are Trump’s Aides and Lawyers. Now They Could Be Trial Witnesses.
articles.snippet: The former president is surrounded by people who have provided testimony and evidence to federal investigators. He’s not supposed to discuss the case with any of them.
articles.abstract: The former president is surrounded by people who have provided testimony and evidence to federal investigators. He’s not supposed to discuss the case with any of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Throughout the inquiry into former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of classified material, his insular world at Mar-a-Lago was rife with intrigue, anxiety and competing motives as investigators sought testimony and evidence from some of his closest aides, advisers, lawyers and even members of his Secret Service detail.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: Hoping to Avert Nuclear Crisis, U.S. Seeks Informal Agreement With Iran
articles.snippet: The talks reflect a resumption of diplomacy between the United States and Iran after the collapse of negotiations to restore the 2015 nuclear deal.
articles.abstract: The talks reflect a resumption of diplomacy between the United States and Iran after the collapse of negotiations to restore the 2015 nuclear deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has been negotiating quietly with Iran to limit Tehran’s nuclear program and free imprisoned Americans, according to officials from three countries, in part of a larger U.S. effort to ease tensions and reduce the risk of a military confrontation with the Islamic Republic.
articles.byline: By Michael Crowley, Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: West Coast Dockworkers Reach Contract Deal With Port Operators
articles.snippet: After a year of prolonged negotiations that have led to delays and declines in cargo, the two sides agreed to a new contract with help from the Biden administration.
articles.abstract: After a year of prolonged negotiations that have led to delays and declines in cargo, the two sides agreed to a new contract with help from the Biden administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a year of contract negotiations that resulted in numerous delays and a decline in the movement of cargo at ports along the West Coast, union dockworkers and port operators have reached a tentative deal set to last for six years.

articles.headline: As Ties to China Turn Toxic, Even Chinese Companies Are Breaking Them
articles.snippet: Companies are moving headquarters and factories outside the country and cleaving off their Chinese businesses. It’s not clear the strategy will work.
articles.abstract: Companies are moving headquarters and factories outside the country and cleaving off their Chinese businesses. It’s not clear the strategy will work.
articles.lead_paragraph: As it expanded internationally, Shein, the rapidly growing fast fashion app, progressively cut ties to its home country, China. It moved its headquarters to Singapore and de-registered its original company in Nanjing. It set up operations in Ireland and Indiana, and hired Washington lobbyists to highlight its U.S. expansion plans as it prepares for a potential initial public offering this year.

articles.headline: Watch Out for ‘Junk’ Fees When Booking Travel Online
articles.snippet: Hotels and airlines struggling to recoup their losses from the pandemic have been including more hidden charges. Don’t fall for them.
articles.abstract: Hotels and airlines struggling to recoup their losses from the pandemic have been including more hidden charges. Don’t fall for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many of us are desperate to travel this summer after a pandemic stifled our plans for years. But travelers — and I’m sorry to be a killjoy — should beware: Those seemingly cheap plane tickets or hotel rooms advertised online may be a trap to make you spend more than anticipated.

articles.headline: The Radical Strategy Behind Trump’s Promise to ‘Go After’ Biden
articles.snippet: Conservatives with close ties to Donald J. Trump are laying out a “paradigm-shifting” legal rationale to erase the Justice Department’s independence from the president.
articles.abstract: Conservatives with close ties to Donald J. Trump are laying out a “paradigm-shifting” legal rationale to erase the Justice Department’s independence from the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump responded to his latest indictment by promising to appoint a special prosecutor if he’s re-elected to “go after” President Biden and his family, he signaled that a second Trump term would fully jettison the post-Watergate norm of Justice Department independence.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Swan, Charlie Savage and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Oregon Town’s Marijuana Boom Yields Envy in Idaho
articles.snippet: Tax revenue has surged since cannabis stores opened in Ontario, Ore., fueling a push in neighboring Idaho to legalize sales and get in on the action.
articles.abstract: Tax revenue has surged since cannabis stores opened in Ontario, Ore., fueling a push in neighboring Idaho to legalize sales and get in on the action.
articles.lead_paragraph: For John Leeds, the hour-and-a-half commute to and from his job as assistant manager at Treasure Valley Cannabis Company is exhausting, but logistically unavoidable.

articles.headline: European Central Bank Raises Rates to Highest Level Since 2001
articles.snippet: Inflation is “projected to remain too high for too long,” the central bank said as it raised interest rates by a quarter point, and signaled more increases may be coming.
articles.abstract: Inflation is “projected to remain too high for too long,” the central bank said as it raised interest rates by a quarter point, and signaled more increases may be coming.
articles.lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank raised interest rates to their highest level in more than two decades on Thursday and warned that there was further to go in order to stamp out inflation.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Upholds Native American Adoption Law
articles.snippet: At issue in the case was whether a law aimed at keeping Native American adoptees within tribes is constitutional.
articles.abstract: At issue in the case was whether a law aimed at keeping Native American adoptees within tribes is constitutional.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Thursday upheld a 1978 law aimed at keeping Native American adoptees with their tribes and traditions, handing a victory to tribes that had argued that a blow to the law would upend the basic principles that have allowed them to govern themselves for years.
